column2502: The programme is led/managed by Resurgence which is implemented as projects in different countries. The projects are deployed with relevant partners and targets are collaboratively decided with partners in that country/city. The DARAJA programme target/pledge has been prepared by the Resurgence team and reviewed by the Resurgence Board.
column2503: We are using a formal M&E procedure but it is not fully aligned with R2R's framework.
column2505: DARAJA has a broad programme level M&E framework which will be adapted for each geographical context and for the specific interventions which will be codesigned with the local communities and stakeholders. Each projects’ M&E aligns to the programme level M&E, although it can add components to it based on the local context and the country partner’s expertise. The M&E framework involves multiple data collection methods including household surveys, and at least two rounds of data collection - baseline and endline. It uses 2-3 analytical frameworks. Work is ongoing to strengthen parts of the M&E framework such as socioeconomic benefits.

column2505: To date, ORRAA has used the M&E procedures of our founding partner, the Global Resilience Partnership. ORRAA is now designing its own M&E procedures (fully aligned with R2R) to track development towards our ultimate outcomes. We expect to complete this process in 2023.
column2506: No, we are not ready yet but we are working to be in the future.
column2508: ORRAA’s mission is to catalyse the investment of at least US$500 million into coastal and ocean natural capital through the development and deployment of finance products that build the resilience of 250 million climate vulnerable coastal people, by 2030.   To do this ORRAA is supporting the development of a pipeline of investible projects that deliver benefits for the Ocean and coastal communities. As the number of projects grow, and as individual projects scale, ORRAA expects to report greater impact. This impact will be measured through formalised M&E procedures which will be finalised in 2023.

column2115: The Alliance’s MEL Team will adopt an adaptive and comprehensive management approach to monitor programs' outcome. The programme will also utilise the multi-faceted web and mobile based integrated technology platform being developed jointly by the Alliance, Esri, WRI and KPMG to accurately track progress in near real-time.

column2505: The Alliance’s M&E procedure will focus on:  · formative evaluation: monitoring of programme design in the initial phases inform ongoing implementation;  · plan comparisons: testing efficacy of alternative interventions or controls against predetermined indicators of outcome success;  · process evaluation: monitoring for analysis and performance management; and  · summative evaluation: evaluating results of programme activities against targets ensuring that information is analysed, disseminated and used by programme stakeholders in a timely manner.

column2508: The Global EverGreening Alliance’s Restore Africa Programme has been launched in May 2022, which aims to restore 1.9 million hectares of land and directly support 1.5 million smallholder farming families, across six African countries – Kenya, Ethiopia, Malawi, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. The Alliance will work with its members on the ground to design the program and develop a program plan in the following months.

column2505: We track impacts along the following core metrics for all countries: Measures of Success:  People  Number of safer people (depth): The number of men and boys, and women and girls, who have been made safer, protected from their home collapsing or homelessness in the event of a disaster.    Number of safer buildings: The number of homes and schools structurally strengthened to withstand disasters, with upgrades to living conditions made for  improved health and economic opportunities.    Number of people reached (breadth): The number of men and boys, and women and girls, who have been reached with access to finance and/or information about improved housing.      Policy and Systems Change   Number of organizations changed: The number of organizations whose systems and processes are changed, as an indicator of systems change.    Number of policies improved and their reach: The number of policies (regulations, standards, social housing policies) changed or established, as an indicator of systems change.    Money    Value of assets protected: The estimated market value of housing assets protected from loss during disasters.      Value of assets leveraged:  The investments leveraged in safer housing by others         Technology  Technology or engineering modules or products completed: The number of technology or engineering design resources, apps, platforms, and other tools developed and in use to enable the supply of more resilient housing at scale    C02 emissions saved: The reduction in CO2 emissions resulting from structurally strengthening and improving homes, instead of building new homes.
column2506: Yes, we can submit the plan statement now.

column2505: We will develop a theory of change with all partners, forming the initial set up of a Learning & Impact Approach to track the effectiveness, impact, and sustainability of the initiative. This will include identifying key descriptive statistics and reporting against the outputs and outcomes of the theory of change. In addition, the Learning & Impact Approach includes liaising with supported regions to gather key statistics about the local achievements, tracking both efficiency and effectiveness measures given the complexity of the systems we are trying to change: # of innovative policies developed, % of budgetary allocations for adaptive capacity allocated, # of stakeholders engaged in deliberative processes, regional portfolio effectiveness (spread of options for exploring alternatives and connections and for testing the way forward).

column2499: Each city that joins the Cities Race to Resilience has its own unqiue context and challenges. For this reason, once a city joins the Cities Race to Resilience, they pledge to undertake a community-wide climate risk and vulnerability assessment that also includes all vulnerable communities. Thus the 'diagnostics' is contingent on each particular city, and not the initiative itself.
column2501: No, but we will consult them to validate this pledge and update it accordingly.
column2503: We are using a formal M&E procedure aligned with R2R's framework.
column2505: All members (cities) are expected to report their progress annually via a relevant reporting platform, such as the CDP ICLEI Track, which is aligned with the Race to Resilience Metrics.
column2506: No, we are not ready yet but we are working to be in the future.
column2508: Each member (city) plans to use knowledge and scientific evidence available to them, including data and spatial analysis, for decision-making and action, and outline interim targets and milestones as part of a long-term commitment for citywide action. This is unique to each city and its location, and we expect that those cities who have committed to Cities Race to Resilience will have reported on their actions and progress on commitments to a relevant reporting platform by the end of 2022.
column2510: This submission is not BY ANY MEANS an accurate reflection of how many people will be impacted by city resilient actions via their commitments by joining Cities Race to Resilience.  This submission is based ONLY on the 51 cities from around the world who have already joined the Cities Race to Resilience, noting that as an ongoing initiative, the number of cities joining will continuously grow. Furthermore, please note that - in terms of actual impact on population - figures are generalised, i.e. population numbers have been calculated based on the latest, available census data for each city and totalled per country. However, please note that these numbers are NOT a reliable measure of resilience impact, as they are a) the total population of a given city NOT necessarily the actual constituents who would benefit from resilient activities or commitments, and b) the commitments made by each city do not necessarily transfer into direct, quantifiable/measurable impacts. Finally, please note that the population figures per city are based on what is publicly available and is not always up to date, i.e. some city population figures are from 2016 and are therefore out-of-date. Therefore, it must be reiterated that this survey cannot and does not capture an accurate reflection of the impact of cities joining Cities Race to Resilience.

column2504: We are not monitoring the progress of our members. We are designing an M&E procedure to assess the impact of Arsht-Rock’s work (including its partnerships and initiatives kickstarted through the Extreme Heat Resilience Alliance).
column2505: Arsht-Rock is designing an M&E system to assess and report to donors and partners on the impacts of our work. We will utilize well-known data collection software Kobo Toolbox to gather qualitative and quantitative data from Arsht-Rock’s initiatives, including those linked to the Extreme Heat Resilience Alliance. This data will correspond to 5-10 high-level indicators which track key metrics (e.g., number of people reached by these initiatives). The development of the M&E system is linked to Arsht-Rock’s Theory of Change. We expect that our M&E system will be in place and functional by Fall 2022.
